Database Schema Design (Using PostgreSQL with Sequelize or Prisma)

Since you’re using Express and likely Node.js, I'd recommend PostgreSQL for structured data with relationships.

1. Users Table

sql
CREATE TABLE users (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  email TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL,
  password TEXT NOT NULL, -- Hashed
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now(),
  updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);
  • Stores basic user info.

2. Dogs Table

sql
CREATE TABLE dogs (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  breed TEXT,
  birthdate DATE,
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);
  • Links each dog to a user.

3. Behaviors Table

sql
CREATE TABLE behaviors (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  name TEXT NOT NULL UNIQUE,
  description TEXT
);
  • Stores predefined behaviors (e.g., "Sit," "Stay"), but can be extended.

4. User-Defined Behaviors Table (if users can create their own behaviors)

sql
CREATE TABLE user_behaviors (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  description TEXT
);
  • Allows custom behaviors per user.

5. Dog-Behaviors (Assigning Behaviors to Dogs)

sql
CREATE TABLE dog_behaviors (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  dog_id UUID REFERENCES dogs(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  behavior_id UUID REFERENCES behaviors(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  user_behavior_id UUID REFERENCES user_behaviors(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  proficiency_level INTEGER DEFAULT 0, -- 0 (new) → 5 (mastered)
  next_review_date TIMESTAMP, -- For spaced repetition
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);
  • Links behaviors to specific dogs and tracks progress.

6. Training Sessions

sql
CREATE TABLE training_sessions (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  dog_behavior_id UUID REFERENCES dog_behaviors(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  success_rate INTEGER CHECK (success_rate BETWEEN 0 AND 100),
  duration_minutes INTEGER,
  notes TEXT,
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);
  • Tracks training session outcomes.

How Spaced Repetition Fits In

You mentioned using the open-spaced-repetition npm module. You’ll likely need:

  • A function that updates next_review_date in dog_behaviors after a training session
  • This function would run whenever a user logs a session, using the result to adjust the review date based on SRS.

Example pseudocode:

javascript
import { schedule } from "open-spaced-repetition";

async function updateSpacedRepetition(dogBehaviorId, successRate) {
  const dogBehavior = await db.dogBehaviors.findOne({ where: { id: dogBehaviorId } });

  const newSchedule = schedule({
    lastReview: dogBehavior.next_review_date,
    grade: successRate > 80 ? 5 : successRate > 60 ? 3 : 1, // Adjusting SRS grade
  });

  await db.dogBehaviors.update({
    where: { id: dogBehaviorId },
    data: { next_review_date: newSchedule.nextReview }
  });
}

Tech Stack Recommendation

  • Backend: Node.js (Express) with PostgreSQL
  • ORM: Prisma or Sequelize
  • Auth: Firebase Auth or Auth0 (simpler than rolling your own auth)
  • Hosting: Railway, Render, or Supabase

Updated Database Schema (PostgreSQL)

Since behaviors are per dog and fully customizable, we’ll store them at the per-dog level instead of a global behavior list. Training sessions will contain multiple reps, each rated separately to update the spaced repetition schedule.

1. Users Table

No changes, just storing user info.

sql
CREATE TABLE users (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  email TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL,
  password TEXT NOT NULL, -- Hashed
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

2. Dogs Table

Each dog belongs to a single user.

sql
CREATE TABLE dogs (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  breed TEXT,
  birthdate DATE,
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

3. Behaviors Table

Each dog has its own list of behaviors.

sql
CREATE TABLE dog_behaviors (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  dog_id UUID REFERENCES dogs(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  name TEXT NOT NULL, -- "Sit", "Stay", "Heel", etc.
  description TEXT,
  proficiency_level INTEGER DEFAULT 0, -- 0 (new) → 5 (mastered)
  next_review_date TIMESTAMP, -- Used for spaced repetition
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

4. Training Sessions

A training session is a time when the user works with their dog on one or more behaviors.

sql
CREATE TABLE training_sessions (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  dog_id UUID REFERENCES dogs(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  youtube_link TEXT, -- Optional link to session video
  notes TEXT,
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

5. Training Reps (Each Attempt at a Behavior)

A training session consists of multiple repetitions of behaviors. Each rep is a single instance of the dog responding to a command.

sql
CREATE TABLE training_reps (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  session_id UUID REFERENCES training_sessions(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  dog_behavior_id UUID REFERENCES dog_behaviors(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  success BOOLEAN NOT NULL, -- Whether the dog successfully performed the behavior
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

Spaced Repetition Logic

We'll use the open-spaced-repetition npm module to adjust next_review_date for each behavior based on training reps.

How it Works

  1. A user runs a training session for their dog.
  2. Each time they give a command (rep), they mark whether the dog succeeded or failed.
  3. The system calculates a success rate for the session.
  4. It updates the next review date for that behavior based on spaced repetition.

Updating Spaced Repetition Schedule

Whenever a training session is logged, we calculate a rating from 1-5 (similar to Anki):

  • 5 (Easy): Dog got it right almost every time.
  • 3 (Good): Dog got it right ~60-80% of the time.
  • 1 (Hard): Dog struggled and got it right <60% of the time.

We use this rating to update the review schedule.

Example Code (Express API)

javascript
import { schedule } from "open-spaced-repetition";
import { db } from "./db"; // Assuming you use Prisma or Sequelize

async function updateSpacedRepetition(dogBehaviorId) {
  const reps = await db.trainingReps.findMany({
    where: { dog_behavior_id: dogBehaviorId },
  });

  // Calculate success rate
  const totalReps = reps.length;
  const successfulReps = reps.filter(rep => rep.success).length;
  const successRate = (successfulReps / totalReps) * 100;

  // Convert success rate into spaced repetition grade
  let grade = successRate > 80 ? 5 : successRate > 60 ? 3 : 1;

  // Get the last review date for this behavior
  const behavior = await db.dogBehaviors.findOne({
    where: { id: dogBehaviorId },
  });

  // Calculate next review date
  const newSchedule = schedule({
    lastReview: behavior.next_review_date || new Date(),
    grade,
  });

  // Update the database
  await db.dogBehaviors.update({
    where: { id: dogBehaviorId },
    data: { next_review_date: newSchedule.nextReview },
  });
}

Updated Database Schema

sql
CREATE TABLE users (

);

CREATE TABLE dogs (

  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()

Each behavior belongs to a user and can be assigned to multiple dogs.

sql
CREATE TABLE behaviors (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,

A user assigns a behavior to a specific dog, and progress is tracked separately.

sql
CREATE TABLE dog_behaviors (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  dog_id UUID REFERENCES dogs(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  behavior_id UUID REFERENCES behaviors(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  proficiency_level INTEGER DEFAULT 0, -- 0 (new) → 5 (mastered)
  next_review_date TIMESTAMP, -- Used for spaced repetition
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

✅ Now a user can create "Sit" once, assign it to Dog A & Dog B, but their training progress is tracked separately!

5. Training Sessions (Tracking Each Time a Dog is Trained)

sql
CREATE TABLE training_sessions (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  dog_id UUID REFERENCES dogs(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  youtube_link TEXT, -- Optional link to session video
  notes TEXT,
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

6. Training Reps (Tracking Each Attempt at a Behavior)

Each time a dog is given a command, the success/failure is recorded.

sql
CREATE TABLE training_reps (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT gen_random_uuid(),
  session_id UUID REFERENCES training_sessions(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  dog_behavior_id UUID REFERENCES dog_behaviors(id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
  success BOOLEAN NOT NULL, -- Whether the dog successfully performed the behavior
  created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT now()
);

Updated Spaced Repetition System

Since progress is tracked per dog, the spaced repetition system will apply to dog_behaviors (not behaviors).

Updated Example Code (Express API)

javascript
import { schedule } from "open-spaced-repetition";
import { db } from "./db"; // Assume Prisma or Sequelize setup

async function updateSpacedRepetition(dogBehaviorId) {
  const reps = await db.trainingReps.findMany({
    where: { dog_behavior_id: dogBehaviorId },
  });

  // Calculate success rate
  const totalReps = reps.length;
  const successfulReps = reps.filter(rep => rep.success).length;
  const successRate = (successfulReps / totalReps) * 100;

  // Convert success rate into spaced repetition grade
  let grade = successRate > 80 ? 5 : successRate > 60 ? 3 : 1;

  // Get last review date for this behavior-dog pair
  const dogBehavior = await db.dogBehaviors.findOne({
    where: { id: dogBehaviorId },
  });

  // Calculate next review date
  const newSchedule = schedule({
    lastReview: dogBehavior.next_review_date || new Date(),
    grade,
  });

  // Update database with new review date
  await db.dogBehaviors.update({
    where: { id: dogBehaviorId },
    data: { next_review_date: newSchedule.nextReview },
  });
}

How This Works Now

  1. User adds a behavior → ("Sit", "Heel", "Stay")
  2. User assigns behaviors to specific dogs (Dog A & Dog B get "Sit," Dog C does not)
  3. User runs a training session for Dog A
    • Each rep (attempt) is recorded with success/fail
    • The spaced repetition system updates when "Sit" should be practiced again for Dog A
    • Dog B’s "Sit" remains unaffected

1️⃣ What is Prisma? Should You Use It?

Prisma is an ORM (Object-Relational Mapper) for working with databases in JavaScript/TypeScript. It makes querying and managing PostgreSQL easier than using raw SQL.

💡 Why Use Prisma?

  • Provides auto-generated queries instead of writing SQL manually
  • TypeScript support for safety and autocompletion
  • Easier database migrations (changing your schema over time)

Since you're new to backend work, I highly recommend using Prisma to simplify database interactions.

2️⃣ Setting Up Your Express API with PostgreSQL & Prisma

Let's break it down:
✅ Set up a Node.js Express project
✅ Install Prisma and configure PostgreSQL
✅ Create a simple API endpoint
✅ Run the API in a container with Portainer

Step 1: Initialize a Node.js Project

Run these commands to create your project:

bash
mkdir dog-training-api && cd dog-training-api
npm init -y

Then install Express and Prisma:

bash
npm install express @prisma/client
npm install --save-dev prisma

Step 2: Set Up Prisma & PostgreSQL

2.1 Initialize Prisma

Run:

bash
npx prisma init

This will create a prisma/ folder and a .env file.

2.2 Configure Database Connection

Open the .env file and set your PostgreSQL connection string:

ini
DATABASE_URL="postgresql://user:password@your_postgres_host:5432/dog_training_db"

Replace user, password, and your_postgres_host with your actual PostgreSQL credentials.

Step 3: Define the Database Schema

Edit prisma/schema.prisma:

prisma
generator client {
  provider = "prisma-client-js"
}

datasource db {
  provider = "postgresql"
  url      = env("DATABASE_URL")
}

model User {
  id       String  @id @default(uuid())
  email    String  @unique
  password String
  dogs     Dog[]
}

model Dog {
  id       String   @id @default(uuid())
  name     String
  breed    String?
  user     User     @relation(fields: [userId], references: [id])
  userId   String
}

Run the migration to create the database tables:

bash
npx prisma migrate dev --name init

Step 4: Create a Basic Express API

Create server.js:

javascript
import express from "express";
import { PrismaClient } from "@prisma/client";

const app = express();
const prisma = new PrismaClient();

app.use(express.json()); // Middleware for JSON parsing

// ✅ Test Endpoint
app.get("/", (req, res) => {
  res.json({ message: "API is running!" });
});

// ✅ Create a User
app.post("/users", async (req, res) => {
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  const user = await prisma.user.create({
    data: { email, password },
  });
  res.json(user);
});

// ✅ Get All Users
app.get("/users", async (req, res) => {
  const users = await prisma.user.findMany();
  res.json(users);
});

// ✅ Start the Server
const PORT = 3000;
app.listen(PORT, () => console.log(`🚀 Server running on port ${PORT}`));

Run it with:

bash
node server.js

Then, test in your browser:
➡️ http://localhost:3000/ should return { "message": "API is running!" }

Step 5: Deploying with Docker & Portainer

Since you’re using Portainer, let’s create a Dockerfile:

5.1 Create a Dockerfile

dockerfile
# Use Node.js LTS image
FROM node:18

# Set the working directory
WORKDIR /app

# Copy package.json and install dependencies
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install

# Copy the entire project
COPY . .

# Expose the port
EXPOSE 3000

# Start the app
CMD ["node", "server.js"]

5.2 Create a docker-compose.yml

yaml
version: "3.8"
services:
  api:
    build: .
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@postgres:5432/dog_training_db
    depends_on:
      - postgres
  postgres:
    image: postgres:14
    restart: always
    environment:
      POSTGRES_USER: user
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password
      POSTGRES_DB: dog_training_db
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
volumes:
  postgres_data:

Step 6: Deploy with Portainer

  1. Go to Portainer
  2. Deploy a New Stack
  3. Paste docker-compose.yml
  4. Deploy the Stack
  5. Access API via http://your-server-ip:3000/

javascript
import { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

export default function Home() {
  const [message, setMessage] = useState("");

  useEffect(() => {
    axios.get("http://localhost:3001/").then((res) => {
      setMessage(res.data.message);
    });
  }, []);

  return <h1>{message}</h1>;
}

ChatGPT said:

Yes! We can definitely use Yarn instead of npm. In fact, Yarn workspaces are great for managing a monorepo like Pawgress because they allow dependencies to be shared efficiently across projects.

1️⃣ Switching to Yarn Workspaces

First, remove node_modules and package-lock.json from previous npm usage:

bash
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json backend/node_modules frontend/node_modules

Now, initialize Yarn workspaces at the root of Pawgress/:

bash
yarn init -y

Update package.json in the root directory to enable workspaces:

json
{
  "name": "pawgress",
  "private": true,
  "workspaces": {
    "packages": ["backend", "frontend"]
  }
}

Now install dependencies for both workspaces at once:

bash
yarn install

2️⃣ Setup Backend with Yarn

Move into backend/:

bash
cd backend
yarn init -y

Now install Express and Prisma:

bash
yarn add express @prisma/client
yarn add --dev prisma

Reinitialize Prisma:

bash
yarn prisma init

3️⃣ Setup Frontend with Yarn

Move into frontend/:

bash
cd ../frontend
yarn init -y

Now install Next.js and Axios:

bash
yarn add next react react-dom axios

4️⃣ Running Everything with Yarn

To run the backend:

bash
yarn workspace backend dev

To run the frontend:

bash
yarn workspace frontend dev

To install any package for a specific workspace:

bash
yarn workspace backend add cors dotenv

5️⃣ Running Everything in Docker

Since we’re using Yarn now, we need to update the Dockerfile for both the frontend and backend.

Backend Dockerfile (backend/Dockerfile)

WORKDIR /app
COPY package.json yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install

COPY . .
EXPOSE 3001
CMD ["yarn", "dev"]

Frontend Dockerfile (frontend/Dockerfile)

dockerfile
FROM node:18

WORKDIR /app
COPY package.json yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install

COPY . .
EXPOSE 3000
CMD ["yarn", "dev"]

Now, in docker-compose.yml, make sure it's still configured correctly:

yaml

  backend:
    build: ./backend
    ports:
      - "3001:3001"

      POSTGRES_USER: user
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password
      POSTGRES_DB: pawgress_db
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data

  postgres_data:

Run Everything

You said:
do i need a dockerfile in both backend and frontend folders, or only top level?
ChatGPT said:

You can structure your Docker setup in two ways:

1️⃣ Dockerfiles in backend/ and frontend/ (recommended for modularity)
2️⃣ A single Dockerfile at the root (simpler, but less flexible for separate services)

Since Pawgress is a monorepo with two separate services (backend & frontend), I strongly recommend keeping separate Dockerfiles inside backend/ and frontend/. This allows for better service isolation and works well with Docker Compose.

1️⃣ Keeping Separate Dockerfiles (Recommended)

✅ Each service is containerized independently
✅ Better caching & builds only affected parts
✅ Easier to scale & modify services separately

Folder Structure:

pgsql
Pawgress/
│── backend/
│   ├── Dockerfile
│   ├── server.js
│── frontend/
│   ├── Dockerfile
│   ├── pages/
│── docker-compose.yml
│── package.json (with Yarn workspaces)
│── yarn.lock

backend/Dockerfile

dockerfile
FROM node:18

WORKDIR /app

# Copy root package.json & yarn.lock for workspace install
COPY ../../package.json ../../yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install

# Copy backend code
COPY . .
EXPOSE 3001
CMD ["yarn", "dev"]

frontend/Dockerfile

dockerfile
FROM node:18

WORKDIR /app

# Copy root package.json & yarn.lock for workspace install
COPY ../../package.json ../../yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install

# Copy frontend code
COPY . .
EXPOSE 3000
CMD ["yarn", "dev"]

docker-compose.yml

yaml
version: "3.8"
services:
  backend:
    build: ./backend
    ports:
      - "3001:3001"
    environment:
      - DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@postgres:5432/pawgress_db
    depends_on:
      - postgres
  frontend:
    build: ./frontend
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    depends_on:
      - backend
  postgres:
    image: postgres:14
    restart: always
    environment:
      POSTGRES_USER: user
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password
      POSTGRES_DB: pawgress_db
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
volumes:
  postgres_data:

🚀 Now, run everything:

bash
docker-compose up --build

✅ Each service is built & run separately
✅ Frontend waits for backend
✅ Backend waits for Postgres

2️⃣ Using a Single Dockerfile at Root (Not Recommended)

This approach combines everything into one container, making it harder to scale later. If you want this:

Dockerfile (at root level)

dockerfile
FROM node:18

WORKDIR /app

COPY package.json yarn.lock ./
RUN yarn install

COPY . .
EXPOSE 3000 3001
CMD ["sh", "-c", "cd backend && yarn dev & cd frontend && yarn dev"]

Then, just run:

bash
docker build -t pawgress . && docker run -p 3000:3000 -p 3001:3001 pawgress

🔴 Why this isn't ideal:

  • ❌ Both frontend & backend in a single container (bad for separation)
  • ❌ If one service crashes, the whole container restarts
  • ❌ Not scalable (harder to deploy backend & frontend separately later)

Final Recommendation: ✅ Separate Dockerfiles

👉 Use backend/Dockerfile, frontend/Dockerfile, and docker-compose.yml

You said:
next ran correctly but I got this, what is it?
ChatGPT said:

The error you’re seeing is a React hydration error in Next.js. This happens when the server-rendered HTML doesn’t match what React renders on the client side.

🔍 Possible Causes & Fixes

1️⃣ Client-Only Code Running on the Server (SSR Issue)

  • If you're using window, document, or localStorage, wrap them in:
javascript
if (typeof window !== "undefined") {
  // Run client-side code here
}
  • Or use Next.js’s dynamic import with no SSR:
javascript
import dynamic from "next/dynamic";

const Component = dynamic(() => import("./Component"), { ssr: false });

2️⃣ Using Date.now(), Math.random(), or Other Changing Values

  • If you're rendering timestamps, random numbers, or external data that changes between server and client, move them inside a useEffect:
javascript
import { useState, useEffect } from "react";

export default function Page() {
  const [time, setTime] = useState(null);

  useEffect(() => {
    setTime(Date.now());
  }, []);

  return <div>Time: {time}</div>;
}

3️⃣ Dark Mode Extensions (Like Dark Reader)

  • Your error mentions data-darkreader-mode="dynamic", which means a browser extension is modifying the HTML before React loads.
  • Try disabling Dark Reader (or similar extensions) and reload the page.

4️⃣ Invalid HTML Tag Nesting

  • Check your components for invalid nesting, like:
jsx
<p>
  <div>Wrong nesting</div>
</p>

Instead, fix it:

jsx
<p>
  <span>Correct nesting</span>
</p>

✅ How to Fix It

1️⃣ Disable SSR on the affected component
2️⃣ Wrap client-side code in useEffect
3️⃣ Ensure consistent data between server and client
4️⃣ Disable browser extensions and test again

Certainly! Here's a quick README for the project you've set up so far:

Pawgress 🐾

Pawgress is a dog training app designed to help owners track their dogs' training progress using spaced repetition. The app allows users to add and assign behaviors to multiple dogs, log training sessions, and track the progress of individual training reps. Users can manage their own training sessions, assign behaviors to dogs, and receive reminders for spaced repetition practice.

Project Structure

This repository uses a monorepo structure with Yarn Workspaces, containing both the backend and frontend of the app.

  • backend/: The backend API built with Express and Prisma for interacting with the database.
  • frontend/: The frontend of the app built with Next.js (React), serving the web interface for users to interact with.

Getting Started

1️⃣ Clone the Repository

First, clone the repository to your local machine:

bash
git clone https://github.com/your-username/pawgress.git
cd pawgress

2️⃣ Install Dependencies

Run the following command to install all dependencies for both the frontend and backend:

bash
yarn install

3️⃣ Set Up Environment Variables

Make sure you have a .env file in both the frontend and backend directories (if you're not using Docker). You'll need to specify any necessary environment variables, such as database URLs, API keys, etc.

For local development, you might add variables like:

env
# In backend/.env
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://user:password@localhost:5432/pawgress_db

For production, you'll need to ensure these variables are set in your Docker container or server environment.

4️⃣ Run the Project Locally

You can run both the frontend and backend using Yarn Workspaces. Use the following commands:

  • Backend (API):
    To run the backend API:

    bash
    yarn workspace backend dev

  • Frontend (Web Interface):
    To run the frontend web app:

    bash
    yarn workspace frontend dev

Both services will run in parallel on different ports (by default, frontend on 3000 and backend on 3001).

5️⃣ Running with Docker (Optional)

If you want to run the entire app using Docker and Docker Compose, you can use the docker-compose.yml to set up the services:

  1. Build and start the containers:

    bash
    docker-compose up --build

  2. The frontend will be available at http://localhost:3000, and the backend API will be at http://localhost:3001.

6️⃣ Testing the Project

Once the app is running, you can test the backend API by visiting:

  • Backend API: http://localhost:3001
  • Frontend Web Interface: http://localhost:3000

You can start creating dogs, behaviors, and track training sessions!

Project Overview

Pawgress allows users to track dog training using a spaced repetition system. Here's a summary of the key features:

  • User Authentication (not yet implemented)
  • Multiple Dogs per User
  • Behavior Library (fully customizable)
  • Track Training Sessions (success/failure rate for reps)
  • Spaced Repetition Integration: Reminders to train based on past sessions (coming soon)

Technologies Used

  • Backend:
